title: John Lithgow on His Satirical Poems
text:
Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

The actor John Lithgow’s new book, “Dumpty: The Age of Trump in Verse,” is a book of satirical poetry. On this week’s podcast, Lithgow says that he wasn’t the likeliest person to write a book addressing contemporary politics.

“I’m basically a fairly spineless person, politically,” Lithgow says. “I have my passionate politics but I keep them to myself. There’s something in me that edits myself because I’m an actor, because I feel hesitant to trade on my celebrity — to the extent that I have any — to put forth my own political opinions. But the Trump era has sort of changed that. I think it’s happened with a lot of people. You just become more vocal because you’re more distressed by the situation.”

Image

Leigh Bardugo, who’s written best-selling books like “Six of Crows” for young adults, visits the podcast this week to discuss her first novel for adults, “Ninth House.” The novel, set at a fictionalized Yale, is about a young woman with a very troubled past who has the rare ability to see ghosts. “Fantasy almost always operates as some kind of metaphor for what we’re experiencing in the real world or real life,” Bardugo says. The character’s “ability to see through the veil, to see things that other people can’t, is very much a metaphor for the way that women are ignored and not believed when they speak.”
description: The actor talks about “Dumpty: The Age of Trump in Verse,” and Leigh Bardugo discusses “Ninth House.”
